content.question:
Corripuere viam interea, qua semita monstrat.

Iamque ascendebant collem, qui plurimus urbi

imminet adversasque aspectat desuper arces.

Miratur molem Aeneas, magalia1 quondam,

(5) miratur portas strepitumque et strata viarum.

Instant ardentes Tyrii: pars ducere muros

molirique arcem et manibus subvolvere saxa,

pars optare locum tecto et concludere sulco;2

iura magistratusque legunt sanctumque senatum;

(10) hic portus alii effodiunt; hic alta theatris

fundamenta locant alii, immanesque columnas

rupibus excidunt, scaenis decora alta futuris.

Qualis apes aestate nova per florea rura

exercet sub sole labor, cum gentis adultos

(15) educunt fetus, aut cum liquentia mella

stipant3 et dulci distendunt nectare cellas,

aut onera accipiunt venientum, aut agmine facto

ignavum fucos4 pecus a praesepibus5 arcent;6

fervet opus redolentque thymo fragrantia* mella.

1magalia, -ium, n. pl.: huts

2sulcus, -i, m.: trench, furrow

3stipo, are: cram, pack

4fucus, -i, m-: drone

5praesepe, -is, n.: cell (in a hive)

6arceo, -ere: keep off *also spelled fragrantia in some texts

In the passage above, the shipwrecked Aeneas and Achates make their way to Carthage, and Aeneas gets his first view of the city. Vergil's full description allows us to see Carthage through Aeneas' eyes. In a well-developed essay, identify the admirable qualities of Carthage that emerge as Aeneas surveys the city, and discuss the techniques Vergil uses to convey Aeneas' feelings about Carthage.

BE SURE TO REFER SPECIFICALLY TO THE LATIN TO SUPPORT THE POINTS YOU MAKE IN YOUR ESSAY. Do NOT simply summarize what the passage says.

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2

skill.text: 3.A: Develop an interpretation of a Latin text.
